newsitem.title: USA: US CORPORATE BONDS-New-issue indigestion in market.
newsitem.headline: US CORPORATE BONDS-New-issue indigestion in market.

text.p: Trouble with new junk bonds issues was the main focus of attention on Monday, as the U.S. corporate bond market closed largely unchanged on a slow day of trading, market players said.

Throughout the day, news leaked out that underwriters were restructuring junk bond deals and increasing price talk levels. Gridlock, caused by a traffic jam of new issues, was cited as the main reason for the unfriendly conditions.
Dissatisfied with the current market, Boyd Gaming Corp decided to pull its $250 million junk bond offering via Salomon Brothers.
The company said it planned to relaunch the offering at a later date when pricing conditions improved.
West Coast Entertainment also increased price talk on its $110 million issue (B2/B) to 11 percent to 11 1/4 percent from 10 5/8 to 10 7/8 due to weakened investor demand, sources said.
Credit Suisse First Boston, which was expected to price the offering last Friday, was still working with investors on Monday afternoon, they added.
Two other deals were restructured to accommodate the more treacherous market:

-Adelphia Communications Corp and Smith Barney Inc changed the company's $300 million two-part offering to $150 million in eight-year bonds and $150 million in cash-pay exchangeable preferred stock. Originally, the company hoped to sell 10-year bonds and exchangeable preferred stock that paid-in-kind.

-Glasstech Inc was rumored to have shortened the maturity of $85 million offering to eight-years from 10-years as well as to have added an equity kicker to the deal in the form of warrants. Officials at lead underwriter CIBC Wood Gundy Securities Corp declined to comment.
Since last week, the onslaught of new issues, coupled with weakness in the Treasury and stock markets, has pushed prices of outstanding junk bonds lower.
The price component of weekly returns declined 0.11 percent last week, according to a Salamon Brothers report.

Martin Fridson, head of high-yield bond strategy at Merril Lynch & Co, said it was natural for the high-yield market to experience such price swings as issuers crowd to market in order to tap favorable rates.
Junk bond prices were unchanged in modest trading on Monday.
High-grade bond spreads tracked Treasuries on Monday on similarly sluggish trading volume.
"The (secondary) market is going to be dead before the holiday, unless the (Federal Open Market Committee) decides to do something," said one investment-grade bond trader.
He said even the price of last week's RJR Nabisco bond deal, which was recently freed to trade, was unchanged from its when-issued level.
In other markets, the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 14.93 points to close at 7672.79.
U.S. Treasuries retraced recent gains on Monday as strong housing sales and a improved Chicago purchasing managers' survey put pressure on the market.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury dropped 17/32 to close at 97-30/32, yielding 6.79 percent.
